title: Using STEM Techniques to Investigate TeO2 as a Back-Contact Material in CdTe Solar Cells
content: Solar cell technology has become increasingly important as humanity shifts to renewable energy sources due to climate change and increasing scarcity of nonrenewable sources. In addition to the traditional Si based cells, CdTe can also be used as a solar energy material. Despite having a high theoretical efficiency [1], CdTe devices do not match current Si device performance, with CdTe only reaching an energy conversion efficiency of 22.3% [2] compared to Si cells at 26.1% efficiency [3]. Thus, raising the efficiency of CdTe-based solar cells is a primary concern for those working on them.
